review_title: Supportive low level management, corporate is too bureaucratic
pros: Some programs are well organized and have amazing low level managers who are extremely supportive and hands on to help you succeed. It depends on the program you are working in. The company offers good benefits - pension, affordable health insurance, tons of educational opportunities. Easy to navigate EMR system. Receive mileage for travel. CEU opportunities. Some work from home ability.
cons: -Extremely low pay with small raises that everyone receives, yet are reported to be “performance based.” -Corporate is consistently asking for staff to do more (increased documentation requirements, increase caseload) without paying staff more. At some points, taking advantage of staff who work hard and want to please others so staff do not push back on increased expectations. -at the corporate level, things are too bureaucratic. Policies are rolled out by division, despite there being a variety of programs within One division who all operate differently. Policies are then not enforced the same by all programs causing tension and confusion among employees Of different programs. But when policies like pay structure are more beneficial for corporate to implement by program, rather than division they Do so. So when it’s convenient for corporate they Individualize policies but when not, they implement policies that are not specific to each program.

It's not like teaching at a public school - the priorities are different and the student's mental health needs (for obvious reasons) usually outweigh the more traditional parts of the education, but being part of their progress is very rewarding.

review_title: Great stated mission but a few weaknesses in the practical application
pros: For a non-profit, JRI offers decent benefits like annual 401k matching, occasional bonuses (that don't quite rise to the level of annual rises in cost of living,  though), PTO, flexible work schedules, etc. And has a great mission and programs that really seem to do a lot of good in the region for the most part.
cons: After several years with JRI, it is still unclear what the supervisor of the program I am involved with actually does to earn their title and salary. There is seemingly very little they are able to give in the way of domain knowledge, helpful guidance and overall participation with the program. Yet, because they have been around a while they have been allowed to remain in their role despite repeated reports from multiple people to their supervisor, one of the JRI executives. JRI gives a lot of airtime to "justice" but sadly this is sometimes not clearly presented beyond words when it comes to fostering clear communication, just power dynamics, and safe spaces for reporting unhealthy dynamics in the actual workplace at times.

pros: In everything they do - JRI shows how much they care about the people they serve, the employees who work here and the mission of the organization.  From the beautifully maintained offices and residential programs, to the exceptional benefits offered to employees, to the commitment to support staff to achieve career advancement within the company, JRI is a role model for what Human Services organizations should look like.  Leadership at every level of the company is passionate about the work, proud of our accomplishments and dedicated to making JRI a welcoming environment for everyone who works here or is provided services by one of  the many outstanding programs.  Staff at JRI are true advocates for social justice, equality and opportunity for all.  Human Services professionals who choose to make a career at JRI will find an organization committed to their success.  Great benefits, tuition reimbursement, competitive compensation, career advancement opportunities, an unheard of pension plan, an inspiring work environment and leadership that truly cares about them.
cons: Not really a con, but you will work hard at JRI, learn a ton, and be rewarded for your efforts.  This is a job where you can really make a difference every single day.  But be prepared to give it 100% every single day.  The people served by JRI deserve nothing less.

pros:
I've worked here for a couple years now and feel like I'm learning every day.  I love the time I spend with the kids and feel very rewarded. I've gotten a lot of training, and feel like my supervisors are invested in my professional development. Compensation has gone up every year that I've been here, and the benefits overall are excellent.  No one else I know in the field has benefits that come close. 

It is true what JRI says about this being a career - for people who are professional and here for the right reasons, you will go far. Lots of promotion from within.  It is a fun work environment where you can grow for years. Unfortunately, this career path is not for everyone, and some people are not a good fit. There has been a lot of change here over the past couple years, for the better in my opinion, but some people struggle with change and being held accountable, which can prompt people to want to leave.
cons: SWCE has grown quite a bit, and more students means more difficult issues to deal with each day. The kids seem to get more behaviorally challenging every year. Somewhat high staff turnover, but not always bad if people are choosing to find careers that are better for them.

review_title: Great agency, but new pay is discouraging
job_title: Intensive Care Coordinator in Jamaica Plain, MA
pros: Great office culture, supportive environment from colleagues to supervisors and management, great benefits package for a non-profit organization, great supervision, and coworkers are thoughtful and appreciative.
cons: The new pay starting in 2017 discourages employees to take time off. How is it that we are able to earn and accrue one week of paid time off (PTO), while only getting paid for half the amount that we would have gotten paid if we worked the entire week? We are discouraged from taking PTO or holidays because it would mean taking a hit on our next paycheck. Furthermore, doing away with training hours, discourages staff from learning new and needed skills in order to provide better quality work for the families that we work with every day. The new compensation package does not promote self care, professional development, better quality work from employees, or appreciation for the work that we do in the community.

pros: The students are worth the stresses that come with the job. Pension is unheard of in this day and age but if you can last 5 years then it's yours. Insurance is offered.
cons:
No breaks, for either 8 or 16 hour shifts. You might get a 15 if you ask and if they have the staff coverage to let you do so. Needless to say, this is incredibly unsafe for the employees and students. 
Having to restrain children and the potential for being physically assaulted. This job does not pay you enough to have injuries that will last you the rest of your life. 
Having to keep track of your own hours which leads to being shorted on hours since their electronic clock in/out system has not worked the entire time of employment there (6 months). 
Being mandated (having to work the next shift) every other week because "that's the way it worked out". A better mandate system than a list of names and dropping the name to the bottom once they've completed the mandate is sorely needed. 
Senior staff constantly asking regular staff to switch/cover shifts due to understaffing. The students need consistency and so do the employees. 
Close/open shifts. 
Splitting hairs on what students on high safeties can or can't do. We are here to help them, not keep them confined and bored out of their heads. That doesn't help anyone and, frankly, sounds like a prison.

pros: residents are very well taken care of
cons: cant get a referral after 3 years from my supervisor as it is against work policy

pros: great co-workers, good benefits and PTO, supportive work environment which is important for the field.
cons: atypical work hours for this position

pros: JRI offers a wide range of opportunities for career growth. There are many opportunities for professional development.
cons: Pay is low for the amount of work expected, although this is more of a systemic issue.

review_title: It's A Nice Place to Work
pros: The administration does listen to lower-level workers.
cons: High turnover rate of employees as residential counselors.

pros: always willing to have discussions regarding various concerns employees have
cons: policies could be a bit more fluid to help employees, considering pandemic

review_title: I finally feel like I belong and am appreciated
job_title: Therapeutic Case Manager in Taunton, MA
pros: Great benefits, amazing team, support and resources, training opportunities, advancement opportunities
cons: pay could be slightly better

review_title: Rewarding job with room for growth!
pros: You are able to create your own schedule however you like as long as you hit 40hrs/wk.  Management allows you to do a combination of work at home/work in the office which is a perk not typical in most agencies.  Agency provides you with a work phone and clinicians are also provided with work laptops.  Management team is ALWAYS available - this includes late at night and on the weekends.  They always answer their phones and provide support 24/7 - it is great to work with such dedicated and supportive management.   Management team also supports their employees' personal and professional development and assists employees in developing long term career goals.  There is a lot of room for growth as JRI community based program is opening new offices across the state of Connecticut. The population served is among the most at-risk youth and families in the state, providing a great experience to sharpen and refine your clinical skills.  Working for JRI has been an incredibly rewarding experience.
cons: This is a high -stress job, as any job in the human service field.  It can be a bit disorganized with the new offices opening but that is only temporary.  The driving can be a bit much at times - clients can be an hour apart from each other.

pros: It has some good benefits
cons: There are high productivity expectations

pros: Great place to work with amazing benefits
cons: The different job locations are far apart from each other

review_title: Great co-workers, out of touch administration
pros: Good Benefits, Paid Training, Options for Further Education
cons: Expectations of overtime, Lack of communication between staff and admin

review_title: Incredible Agency with More Oversight for Programs Needed
pros: Excellent opportunities for growth and professional development, purposeful work, cutting edge trauma informed care, commitment to social justice
cons: Understaffed programs, little oversight of individual programs from corporate, overworked staff, low pay

pros: team oriented, fun, you get to help people every day, leaders are inspiring
cons: hard to hear some of the stories of the clients......

pros: The students were very welcoming
cons:
The staff and supervisors etc.. 
Racist / discriminated against
Make lies about you to get you fired if you dont fit they're profile.

review_title: No future or career path for most
pros: Very secured employment and great direct management team.  Much of the time is easy laid back. Great benefits and retirement package.  Spend alot of time working and help children.  Able to go on very fun trips with the children.
cons:
Very little pay for the amount of daily stress that comes with working with children with behavioral problems.  Upper management seems to listen, but not hear complaints.  Unable to work with family members, spouses, or relationship partners.  Any attempt to improve something is met with little involvement.  Very little support and understanding from management.  

Personally I have worked for the same placement for over 7 years.  In that time the only raise I received was from going from part-time to full-time, form $12 to $12.26.  With no raises in the pipeline in the future.  There is a real possibly that I will work for the company for 10 years and make just as much as a new employee starting at the $12/hr rate.  In economic terms I am actually making less money now than when I started as the cost of living has increased, but my salary has not.

review_title: If it looks good on paper at Meadowridge
pros: Benefits package is good. I enjoyed working with the students and staff at Meadowridge.
cons: As the title says if it looks good on paper says it all. At Meadowridge staffing is low and students are not supported correctly, classrooms are not 6:1 more like 9-12 :1 teacher never have staff in the classroom because they are usually running short. Teachers, clinicans, administrators, nursing, and the cook are counted in ratio during the school day leaving students unsupported, staff not able to get there jobs completed which they then get in trouble for, and over worked staff. At a school where the vision is to treat children as if they are your own I would not want my child at a residential school where staffing numbers are played with in order to help the budget rather then the students. Morale is very low unlike anywhere I have seen and if you were to ask anyone who works there they would be scared to tell you whats really going on because the director threatens your job.

pros: The company is well organized with clear branches and each branch maintaining its own goals and mission.
cons: Egregious injustices are occurring at this institute. As part of its structure, JRI employs people with lived experience. In my opinion, these people are the most critical and beneficial team members for the families we serve. However, these lived experience employers are paid less than a camp counselor. While they are deemed integral by their employees, their compensation insinuates that they are not appreciated by management or the organization as a whole. It is difficult to watch and hear consistently in the office how people who are working hard for 40 hours a week cannot meet their basic needs or support their families. As service providers we always say that it is unjust that people who work full time struggle to survive, so how is it possible that we are placing our employees in the same position.

pros: Strong commitment to social justice. Great benefits. Positive and supportive office culture.
cons: I’ve been an employee of JRI for three years, working in a Boston location. My program is community based and serves youth and families of the city. I’ve loved every minute of my employment. The culture of the office is great, the management team very supportive and the overall JRI benefits generous. The new pay structure, however, is confusing and unfair. Although the paid time off is generous, the new system doesn’t allow me to take it freely. I now need to carefully plan days off (and holidays) to ensure that my paycheck will have enough in it so that I can pay my rent that month. I feel like I need to be a mathematician to figure out the timing of vacation, pay period and my monthly bills. Not to mention getting sick. To be honest, I just don’t get it. This system flies in the face of everything I’ve come to expect and appreciate about JRI. I don’t know if this means the company is headed in a new direction or not, and that makes me sad.

pros:
Working for a company that is profoundly focused on making a difference in a host of different and often challenging communities, an organizational belief that the most impactful and lasting change comes through working collaboratively with our clients as partners, a dedicated CEO who started at the agency as a teacher many years ago and found a very successful career at JRI, an agency that is always looking to develop its employees and promote from within.

JRI was originally founded to serve the most challenging of client populations who were not being otherwise served.  The idea being that JRI provides Justice For All.
cons: While the benefits are fantastic, the monetary compensation is not going to compete with other for-profit agencies.  I have been with the agency in my current position for a little over eight years.  To be fair, I began at JRI Health only a few months before the Great Recession, and I understand that this greatly affected the agency's capacity for increasing salaries.  I would also applaud the agency for doing everything it could to avoid layoffs as much as possible during those trying times.  I would choose job security over regular pay increases any day.

review_title: Tough love works best but all we have is hippie new age clinicians with smiley stickers
pros: It's better than most non degree jobs.  It was a great job when we had good clinicians that had experience dealing with this population on a daily basis and know all the games and tricks the population played.  Now we have clinicians that have no experience except for what some book they read in there masters program said to do on a given situation.
cons: High mentally intense environment working with teens/adults with cognitive and mental disorders.  Clinicians and Management only see the clients two hours a week set the policies and then hide in their offices and allow the staff to be abused by there lack of structure and consequences.  Absolutely no structure or consequences for anything anymore.  A kid can call you every name in the book and refuse to do anything and the next hour you are give them a bowl of ice cream because that is how the clinicians plan it.

pros: The benefits are insanely cheap. The experience is good when the right type of kids are being placed in the correct housing types. Tons of overtime.
cons: They just try to fill beds so houses don't get closed, so community based programs get violent teens from DYS. Frequent injuries and they talk you out of suing or pressing charges. Lack of support from any stuff especially supervisors. Extremely low pay for the jobs you do. Admins will complain about your work but aren't the ones dealing with the kids at the end of the day. None of the supervisors respect admin and no one is ever on the same page. Rules change all the time and no one relays the message. Staff turnover is horrible. Always looking to hire. No way to advance in the company. Popularity contest constantly. Every staff is hooking up with each other too. Bad for business and completely unprofessional.

pros: Strong team environment between employees, worthwhile training.  Some of the management is very empathetic and communicative. The agency is very involved in social justice and it feels great to know you're part of that. Higher management will randomly give incentives which can really help with morale.
cons: Supervision is really subpar. Initial training at hiring is scant, causing multiple mix-ups in the first months/year of employment (not knowing about certain protocol, assessments, formatting, etc). Staffing tends to be on the lower side, causing employees to have to drive -quite literally- all over the state of Connecticut because cases are that scattered. The expectations of paperwork, client contact hours, and meetings to be squeezed into 40 hours when you spend upwards of 20 hours of your workweek driving can be really stressful. Because Massachusetts is a commonwealth state, mileage is 48 cents to the mile, rather than the federal minimum.

review_title: Up near the top for a residential employer.
pros: JRI really invests in its staff with training and supervision. Staff work together closely and are professional while holding each other accountable. Staff grow visibly and so do clients which makes this work very rewarding. This job provides a raise at six months and a year which is more than can be said for most residential employers.
cons: This employer shoots itself in the foot with its low pay. We lose a lot of our new staff due to how tough and demanding the work is. You need a big heart, motivation, honesty, a high stress tolerance and an ability to not take anything personally.  Unfortunately we lose a lot of good people with these qualities because their pay does not reflect their qualifications. Even the raise is not much and does not cover cost of living.

pros: The size of the agency allows for a good benefits package.
cons:
JRI has a good reputation as an agency, but there is wide variation in employee experiences across individual programs--and employees don't get a lot of agency-wide communication/exposure. 
When an individual program is dysfunctional, even toxic, for employees, it goes unaddressed, and can often stay under the radar of the agency's leadership. To use a bad analogy--in some JRI programs, the inmates were running the asylum, and some very questionable mgmt practices go on routinely, resulting in high turnover of some great people, for strictly mgmt reasons.
The new compensation structure is horrible, demoralizing, and borderline exploiting of employees, for reasons which are already well documented here (and the same response to each, beginning with an "I'm sorry if you feel" statement, speaks volumes.

review_title: Salary isnt competitive, but company does incredible work and management cares
pros: Well resourced organization, managers listen and take in employee feedback, review process is very open and honest, generous benefits package, rewarding work, very smart and dedicated employees, felt as if many managers truly had an opendoor policy, great work culture, big organizational announcements were always done as early on as possible, a lot of independence and creativity allowed in many positions. It is a very strong social justice organization that does a lot of everything, if youre a passionate person youll fit right in.
cons: Salary isnt competitive for nonprofits in the Boston area and raises or even COLA are very rare so turnover for new ambitious employees can be rapid so loss of institutional memory is tough, watching your coworkers leave for orgs to do similar work with the same title but for better pay is unfortunately somewhat common, streamlining inter-departmental communication would be very helpful, too many projects rely exclusively on grant funding

review_title: Want to do good work, with little to no support
pros: The ability to schedule your own client time - which unfortunately does only work AFTER the kids get out of school. There are trainings but are hyper focused on one type of intervention techniques. You do get reimbursed for mileage, but have to use your own vehicle.
cons: There is not enough support for clinicians or clinical team.  No organization. Have to use your own vehicle to drive all over the state. A lot of case management and little actual therapy. You almost always work over 40-hours a week, but not compensated for overtime as full-time employees are salaried.  An unmanageable amount of paperwork that needs to be completed in an unrealistic amount of time. Supervisors do not take constructive criticism well or actually apply suggestions to improve office. Little room for growth unless you become close with supervisors.   Believe in "public shaming".

pros: Friendly work environment where staff are well trained and supported. The mission and vision of Meadowridge Academy and JRI can be seen and felt all over campus. Great opportunities for advancement.
cons: Working in a large, therapeutic boarding school requires the type of dedication and energy that is not easily found in most people. This may contribute to what some may perceive as a higher than average turn over rate.

pros:
There are a number of pros to this agency, but the number one thing is the amount of opportunities that it has to offer.  The opportunities may not consist of positions that are available or created yet, but there are plenty of areas that JRI is willing to work on with you to find a position that you has not yet been created, but would be a valuable part of the agency.

The benefits include some of the best you can get in any agency or company.
The paid time off is amazing and accrues up to 180 hours.  You can use that time for whatever event or illness that comes up.  After the 180 hours time goes into Extended Medical Leave, which you can use for any medical issues that may come up.
cons: The only con is the pay.  It is not just this agency, but human services in general.  This is not a criticism of JRI, but the field as a whole.

review_title: Lucky to play a small part in the larger agency
pros:
Working at JRI has been an excellent experience. The agency has a strong mission statement and works hard each and every day to make sure they are striving towards achieving that mission. I have worked for two of the many many different programs within Justice Resource Institute, and have never been happier working within an agency. 
In my experience, everyone who works for Justice Resource Institute does so with a passion for the work, and because they want to. JRI offers many opportunities to move up within the agency, and they strive to help employees make a career out of JRI rather than just a job.
Justice Resource Institute also plays much attention to the well-being of their employees, making sure that they are keeping up with their own self-care and quality of life amongst the difficult situations that this type of work can create.
cons: My only wish for Justice Resource Institute is that there be more inter-program communication and opportunities for more events agency-wide.

review_title: An agency which lives up to its name
pros: Incredible, varied opportunities to acquire comprehensive clinical skills in a multitude of modalities; excellent benefits package; agency does not shy away from embracing emerging and promising practices, in addition to established evidence-based practices; most person-centered, strengths-based agency I have had the opportunity to work for; ability to collaborate with some brilliant minds; as much transparency as possible from CEO regarding administrative/management decisions.
cons: Very low pay; very high pressure/demands; extremely high turnover rate in res.; when morale drops, it drops at an alarming rate of speed; high burnout due in-part to bearing witness to the after-effects of trauma seen in the population served (i.e. the nature of the work, itself), as well as facing systemic barriers which interfere with healing.

pros: There are many positives to being an employee of JRI. JRI's mission and vision is carried out in the community through their vast services and agencies.  Their core values ensure opportunities for their clients to better themselves, their families, and their communities.  This can be said for the employees of JRI as well.  With tuition reimbursement, flexible schedules, and continous trainings and professional development, JRI allows ample support to achieve one's personal goals.  JRI views their employees as their best investment.  JRI make a conscience effort to promote employees from within, thus providing job security and the opportunity to grow within the company.
cons: JRI's IT Infrastructure is lacking for such a prominent company.  Employees can feel the burden of such emotionally driven jobs. Having a reliable  updated  centralized system to streamline the administrative aspect efficiently and utilize more time with clients

review_title: overall a great place to work !
job_title: Overnight Awake Counsulor in Attleboro, MA
pros: while JRI main focus is the health and well-being of the clients they serve, this can't be done without the employees having the tools to make that happen. the pay is fairly competitive with today's market, the benefits are good and the PTO time is generous. all that allows us to focus on why we are here: to serve our clients and to make sure they have what they need to succeed. if you are looking for a place that will put you 1st so that you can do your job to the best of your ability, look no further than JRI !
cons: I have experienced anything negative about JRI. if they could expand into RI, perhaps in the providence area, I could transfer and be closer to home. my commute is 20-25 minutes so in bad weather that can be an issue. other than that, they are really no " cons" about working here.

review_title: Other companies pay more for the same work
pros: Benefits, hours. Was able to go to school and study while working nights. Tuition reimbursement is available.   That's about it.
cons: Pay, hostile work environment to those with political views that differ from the company leadership, understaffed, high turnover. Not much upwards mobility. Lack of funding often creates unsafe work environments because clients aren't receiving the resources they need.

pros: I have worked at JRI for almost ten years.  I started in an entry level position, and over time moved into upper program management.  JRI senior leaders really supported me in getting my masters degree, seeking field specific training, taking on new responsibilities, and making connections in the field.  I can't overstate how supported I've been by so many individuals at JRI during the course of my employment.  Also, the benefits are excellent, and really unparalleled in human services. Most importantly, JRI serves the individuals that no one else can.  I have seen so many success stories here, it has been truly inspiring.
cons: JRI now operates many sites, so the distance between locations can be a challenge at times - depending on your position, you have to be prepared to travel.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Jamaica Plain, MA
pros: Location; work with a variety of clients; great co-workers. Very supportive management. The company has a lot of great programs in Boston and I love being a part of the larger organization.
cons: Focus on billing, making me feel like that's my only worth.

review_title: JRI helps you make a better you whether you're a client or an employee!
job_title: Office Manager in Fall River, MA
pros: Justice Resource Institute is a very welcoming, and caring company. They not only try their best to help their clients succeed but also their workers. They offer great benefits not only such as health and retirement  but also benefits for furthering your education so you can open the door to more opportunities. Also step into any JRI event and you will feel the passion they have for their work. JRI truly believes anyone can be great with a little bit of help, and that's exactly what they are there for. Whether it be a present on Christmas, school supplies for the new school year, or maybe just a little financial help on basic day to day things. Being apart of JRI makes you feel like you're making a difference in people's lives and how many jobs can make you go home and say that.
cons: Only con is I'm not full time.. yet!

pros: JRI is generally invested in employee satisfaction and does a variety of initiatives (surveys, committees, etc) to keep staff happy. Pension plan is a plus. Colleagues are kind and friendly. Leadership is active, competent, and visible. Work is mission driven and focused. Some great people work here and have real loyalty to the organization in a way that can feel like a family without being claustrophobic.
cons: Salaries aren't high in my division and the process for getting increases is a bit opaque. Corporate office offers profession development groups that aren't always well facilitated and thus can feel a bit silly. Healthcare plan is touted as highly competitive and I don't know other comparably sized orgs' plans, but it's still really expensive.

review_title: The best of the best in social services!
pros:
Strength-based, social justice driven organization that has as its central mission to challenge, address and transform health disparities for the most under-served, disadvantaged, and historically overlooked service recipient populations, from child and adult complex trauma survivors to LGBTQ+ clients, individuals living with HIV and AIDS, adults living with severe developmental disabilities, homeless youth, adults and families, children and adolescents in the child welfare or juvenile justice system, and the list goes on and on!

One of the only remaining non-government defined benefit pension plans in New England, and a very robust one at that.

Excellent benefits.

Competitive salary.

Amazing community of colleagues sharing the same overarching mission.

Company embraces diversity, creativity and initiative.
cons: The organization does not have season tickets to any professional sports team that are periodically made available to employees based upon lottery, merit or length of employment (that's seriously about the only CON that I could come up with!)

pros:
Awesome management
Open lines of communication to coworkers, management, & upper management
Flexible time off
Fun staff appreciation/team bonding events
Continuous training (I never feel "left behind")
Excellent resources to prevent stress and burnout

Seriously. If you have a chance to work here, do it. A lot of these types of jobs WILL be stressful by nature, but JRI makes dealing with that stress so much easier with all their opportunities for employee support.
cons:
Somewhat low base pay
Not many open positions (because turnover is so low, which technically is a good sign)

review_title: New compensation package is very disappointing
pros: Talented and supportive co-workers, great supervision, access to trainings, commitment to social justice and trauma informed care
cons: Long hours, unreasonable (and stressful) new productivity standards, taking PTO or attending trainings will have a negative impact on your pay check

pros: Most jobs in the agency are great because you are there to help kids.
cons: Management is not helpful. Most Supervisors or Program Directors think of themselves as above their employees. There is a ton of burn out at this company as they expect you to do everything. Program Directors and Supervisors have the ability to do what they want with their employees which can be extremely unfair to others. Pay is average compared to other places in the field.

pros: This is the first organization/company where I've worked that truly embodies its values. Moreover,  the values and mission match my own personal goals and passions. For a non-profit, the pay is surprisingly good and the benefits are wonderful. I have a great supervisor and feel that her and JRI encourage me to do my best and want me to succeed in the long-term.
cons: There's no parental leave. Finding appropriate forms can be quite difficult. IT seems disorganized (often have someone unaware of the issue and their area of IT does not match the issue)/there are periods where the server malfunctions with odd error messages that IT does not understand. Start dates of benefits and full benefits packages are not well-described. In fact, when reaching out to HR for full documentation on their new supplemental life insurance, it simply did not exist.

review_title: Director of Training and Trauma Response
job_title: Director of Training and Trauma Response in Needham, MA
pros: JRI is committed to the pursuit of social justice and working with vulnerable populations which is something that is an integral part of my life. Having the privilege of working with like minded people has been instrumental for me.  My mentors within the agency have always supported my professional development path and provided me with the supervision and training I needed to be successful in taking on new roles.
cons: The only downside is that the work is so very emotionally charged so you must be disciplined in your self-care practices and maintain a strong work/life balance which the agency supports at all levels.

review_title: Unhealthy work environment just getting unhealthier.
pros: Working to improve the lives of the residents. Medical and tuition benefits
cons: Staff turn over rate has sky rocketed. 90% of staff is over worked and under paid. Absolutely exhausted. By far the most discriminating company that ever worked for. Current administration shows lack of professionalism and respect for staff and labor laws. Staff and residents are often treated as numbers and only certain staff and residents are held to the rules while others are not. Run through a bully system.

job_title: Therapeutic Counselor in New Bedford, MA
pros: Management is phenomenal, training is top notch and paid, benefits are awesome, teamwork is huge in many of their programs, amazing programs that change lives! Some are 5 stars, look them up! Room to grow, and hire from within, paid tuition.
cons: Pay is on lower scale because of being non-profit. This is unfortunate because regardless of how passionate you are about helping people, you cannot live on 12$ an hr.

pros: I really enjoy working for an agency that strives to be the best for not only the people we serve, but for their staff as well. Our agency has built in so many incentives to help staff participate in self-care, and encourages this as well. Our agency looks for ways to incorporate fun into the work day  to help staff de-stress due to the challenging work that goes on day after day. Working for an agency that promotes positive and healthy options to support  their team members is why I have stayed with the agency for more than ten years.
cons: The promotion benefits from annual salary increases do not always off-set cost of living increases. However, the flexible benefits offered from the agency do make it manageable.

pros:
- Possibility of overtime.
- People you work with.
- Easy foot in the door to get work experience.  And you will get a full understanding of it.
-
cons:
- Pay
- Forced shifts when people call out.  Ruins plans all the time
- Place can be dangerous... New rules put the staff in vulnerable positions.

pros:
Great colleagues, supportive and competent supervisors and director.  
Employees at the program level are committed to providing quality of care.
Generous benefits and good trainings.
cons:
Significant increase in "base" productivity expectation in 2017 (from 16 hrs./week to 20 hrs./week)
Total elimination of PTO and training rates.  Thus, significant loss of salary when PTO is taken.

review_title: JRI is a tremendous organization for the clients they serve and the staff they employ!
job_title: Director of Development and Operations in New Britain, CT
pros: I have been working in JRI for nine years. I started off as an Asst. Director of a program and grew to become the leader of JRI's Connecticut Division. In my time in the agency, we have positively impacted the lives of countless youth and often times youth others refused to serve. It has been a very gratifying experience professionally.
cons: Sometimes working with this difficult population can be hard initially while working through their symptoms.

review_title: Love Working for an Organization with a Positive Mission!
pros: This organization is very dedication to its social justice mission and service to marginalized communities and peoples. There are opportunities to receive all kinds of specialized trainings from internal and external program initiatives. Many of their interventions are innovative and at the forefront of trauma-informed care. This organization also take very good care of its employees- the pay is good (relatively speaking for a non-profit), and the benefits package is very generous. There are ample opportunities for advancement within the agency.
cons: I would really love the see the organization come up with a parental leave policy for new parents; I think this would be very in line with the organization's values and goals.

review_title: Creative and Caring Place to Work
job_title: Director of Clinical Quality Management in Needham, MA
pros:
JRI works with staff to help them with career development - many JRI staff have started as direct care staff, teachers, clinical interns and with the support of leadership have moved up in the company - finding their niche - finding where they excel and how they can always focus on providing trauma-informed care to the youth, families, and adults that need it the most.
Great working atmosphere
Creative leadership
Excellent Benefits
cons: can't think of any at this time

pros:
*The staff is amazing as it is diverse
*The organization values your  mental health
* They offer you a good work life balance
* You learn and build a number of skills that are applicable to many types of non-profit, social justice and social work oriented positions. 
* a position where the value of the experience is relative to what you make out of it. 
*Higher-ups are time efficient and effective. Consistant and reliant.
* Hire internally whenever possible, opportunities for growth
cons: *nothing more than the expected challenges of working for a non profit.. Periodic last minute changes, and sometimes having to stay up to finish some work.

pros: JRI puts beliefs into actions - belief that all people deserve opportunities and if they have challenges we can help them achieve their goals. At JRI, this happens in all kinds of ways for different human service populations of children, adults and families. Pretty exciting to be part of this! Great tuition support and benefit package.
cons: Some state agencies have tight budgets so resulting contracts limit salaries and make it harder to attract and keep talented staff. Not enough good people consider human services a career track these days, and it's hard to break thru that mind-set.

pros: The JRI team strives to continuously make changes and efforts to grow as a company and as  a leader of excellent service providers. I personally  have been provided countless opportunities  to learn new skills and interventions via company trainings, experience with clients, and support from my supervisors.  The clinical team has always been there to help guide me both professionally in my cases and paperwork  as well as personally in the development  of my career.
cons: Implementing treatment strategies for our clients can be tough, but seeing a child or family make even small strides is incredibly  rewarding.

review_title: Rewarding work, great people, excellent benefits, and lots of opportunities
pros:
I was stuck in life, stopped college and hadn't finished my degree yet, and while working at a Marriott in my home state of Pennsylvania, my friendliness and customer service was apparently noticed. I was recruited by a division director (a regular guest at the hotel) to come work at a JRI program in the Boston area. I started out as an Admin Assistant at a juvenile justice center. I worked hard at this new position to make it more organized and improve efficiency and happiness for employees at that site -- luckily I had great managers and mentors to support me. My hard work was recognized and appreciated and when the difficult decision was made to close that program (for lack of state-funding to pay staff sufficient wages), I was offered a position at the JRI corporate office in the accounts receivable department (with really no training or experience in that area). Again, I put 110% into my work to not only learn and do the job, but to make improvements where I could and when I had time. During this time, the company also paid my way to complete my degree, which left me with little-to-no student loan debt afterwards.

As the company has exponentially grown (and continues to grow), I was able to be promoted from Accounts Receivable Manager to my current Budget Director role in which I report to the CFO. Meanwhile, my wife and I had two kids in the past 4 years and JRI was flexible enough for me to take some paternity time and then adjust schedule as-needed to meet daycare demands, etc. Next month, I'll have completed 14 years at JRI already and I'm just turning 40 later this year. It's very rare to find these days, but JRI offers a defined pension plan benefit, which means that when I retire, JRI will continue to pay me based on a calculation of my years of service, salary level, and a few other factors (and I don't have to contribute anything to this during my career at JRI). On top of that, I also choose to contribute to JRI's pre-tax 401(k) plan which is matched by JRI up to $800 per year -- so I'm feeling very good about making sure my family is set in my retirement years. Additionally, even though JRI offers excellent health coverage, I'm still on my wife's medical plan at her work, but that allows me to take advantage of another benefit at JRI called the Alternative Health Option, which has paid me an extra $2,000 per year for NOT using JRI's medical coverage -- and once I hit 10 years at the company, that went up to $3,000 per year! Since my wife's plan also has great rates, this pretty much means we get our family health coverage for next to nothing -- we may even make a few bucks on it! Plus, JRI provides free Dental coverage so my entire family is covered at no premium cost to me.

All of those things are great, but what I love the most at JRI are the people, the supervisors, and the mentors that I've had. Also, I love the rewarding feeling that comes in knowing that, in some way, my behind-a-computer-screen budget work is ultimately helping to provide excellent services to the many different clients that JRI serves. I do miss being on the front line and interacting directly with clients, but it's a good feeling to know that JRI has high standards for the services we provide and the physical sites where the work is done. I know these are places that I would feel comfortable sending my own kids if necessary. Most of my friends work at for-profit companies, such as PR firms, and I've seen each of them get laid off or have to switch jobs multiple times in the time I've been at JRI. That's not for me. I love the job security and I love being a part of the JRI family, which is all working to make real differences in the lives of young people and families -- and not just padding someone's pockets at the top of a for-profit company. There are many people at JRI that have been here for 20, 30, 40 years or more -- and many are coming up for retirement soon. I'm one of many examples where my hard work has allowed me to move up the chain quickly, and there are many opportunities coming up at JRI. JRI has literally changed my life for the better and I'm thankful every day that JRI found me and I took the chance to move to Boston and start a career with JRI. I recommend that you do too!
cons: We are busy all the time.  Because of the rapid growth of JRI and the many diverse programs and services we offer, it causes there to be A LOT of work.  It can sometimes be frustrating when you have ideas to improve systems and you simply just can't get to them because of the workload.

review_title: Connected to support staff education and opportunities for learning
pros:
Open to feedback, tools and support for learning and development.
Connection to diverse needs of the communities they serve is a vital part of the Mission of JRI Programs
Benefits, Educational Connection to support degrees
cons: Stakeholders mandates influence criteria of some program financial abilities for staff incomes. Particularly Para Professionals.

pros: Hardworking staff dedicated to making change with families and clients.  Great hands on clinical experience.
cons: Admin had unrealistic expectations for staff. Staff do not feel supported by admin. Staff leave as fast as they get hired- it’s a revolving door making it challenging for the clients and families they serve to have beneficial treatment with constant changes in providers. Admin constantly puts staff down ultimately causing them to resign from a job they are passionate about.  The entire program is EXTREMELY disorganized.

review_title: New CBS Division Compensation Is Unjust
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Jamaica Plain, MA
pros: I have been working with JRI in the Boston area for almost 3 years.  I love the supportive, friendly and professional environment at the CSA.  I enjoy my supervision and colleagues.  I have never felt alone working with our clients with complex trauma & needs.  JRI's benefits and training are great.
cons: The new compensation model for 2017 does not encourage work and life balance.  Not only the base productivity has gone up, the PTO and training rates have been eliminated. I live on a set income so when I take PTO, I would not have enough money to pay rent since the hourly pay rate is barely above the MA minimum wage for non-Master level staff .  For Master level staff it is only $14.42/hour.  Granted, there is an incentive rate if I bill but that is the only focus.  I am just the billing machine!

review_title: You can't find many companies that offer as much as JRI
pros:
Tons of opportunity for advancement or for movement within the agency. 
Lots of opportunity for trainings.
The best benefits at a non-profit I have seen in Massachusetts. 
Lots of vacation time especially after two years. 
Comparable salaries to other agencies and great health insurance. 
After 5 years of working full time, you can start accruing a pension which is unheard of.

Having worked in several different positions and at four different JRI programs I can honestly say you CAN find the right fit but you need to be honest about what you're looking for in a job. While I could make more in a fee for service or blended salary position I know I am unhappy when I have to depend on billing for my income. As a result, I sought out one of the few salaried positions available at my education level and I'm so happy about it.

Some management isn't that great but I've been lucky to have a lot of great supervisors and program directors. If you don't like paperwork maybe try a JRI residential school as direct care staff. If you don't mind it then look into the community-based programs. If you're masters level, well, paperwork is going to be a part of your job no matter what, so figure out how to deal with that. It pays to be patient and to try to find the right position for you at JRI.
cons: Lots of bureaucracy, lots of paperwork. This is often necessary though. Some programs have high turnover rates which can be super stressful.

pros: I have been an employee of JRI for 2 years.  After finding out I could apply for a reimbursement for my college classes, I quickly found all of the information I needed.  Everything is well organized and the company benefits are easily accessible for all employees.  I received my reimbursement quickly and was very happy with the outcome!
cons: No cons that I can think of.  I have been employed at the company for 2 years and have no complaints.  They are very committed to their employees and will  work with you to solve any possible problems that may arise.

review_title: Overall great experience, wonderful supervisor, amazing benefits, but limited opportunity to move up.
job_title: Human Resources Assistant in Westborough, MA
pros: Amazing benefits including excellent health care costs, excellent tuition reimbursement, and offered a great culture that emphasized learning and family values.
cons: Was not given any opportunity to move up within or across the organization. All advancements seemed like there were underlying political reasons and who you are seemed to matter more than what you can do.

pros:
-Client-focused: JRI has incredibly caring employees and is well-known for their work in trauma.  Their in-house trainings are well developed to help employees become trauma-informed and focused on meeting individual client needs.  Programs have full autonomy to implement strategies that work best for the individual client.  There is zero tolerance for mistreatment of clients.  Restraints are utilized for imminent risk of harm to self or others and even then JRI trains on the least restrictive restraints, keeping in mind the safety of the client and staff involved.  The expectation is to de-escalate a situation and help a client regulate without going hands-on. 

-Benefits: Great offerings which includes both 401k and pension plan (after 5 years of employment).  Also some really nice partnerships with colleges to assist staff interested in pursuing a career in clinical work.  There are also times when other benefits are provided dependent on company performance such as a year-end bonus and a student loan assistance scholarship.

-Fulfilling client work: Working with the children is challenging at times but also incredibly rewarding.  It's great seeing them develop while also allowing them opportunities to release the adult burdens placed on them at an early age and re-experience childhood.

-Reputation: JRI is a strong human services firm and many people remain with the company for the long-haul.
cons:
-Very political and hierarchical:  The individuals who progress are great at talking the talk to get where they want to be even if their performance isn't the best.  I witnessed many senior leaders visit the program periodically and barely acknowledge anyone who isn't also in a leadership position (not even a simple hello when staff opened the door for them).  Individuals are told to just go along with what leaders say even if they have a question, concern or suggestion.

-Work in a silo: The culture at each program varies greatly depending on the Program Director and can change drastically when a new Director comes in, with little to no transition.  For example, my program went from one who was transparent, inclusive and developed staff based on their skills and potential, to one who interacted with individuals solely based on their job title and formed their own clique.  Strong performers who once felt optimistic and supported now feel dis-empowered.

Processes vary between programs and there isn't any succinct way to proactively and regularly share best practices.  There is an intranet but not every program/department uses it and the content isn't managed well, if at all.

Rapport between some programs and Corporate departments is strained at times.  Expectations vary and cause great frustration on both sides.  There is a significant control issue at the Corporate level -- they don't seem to trust the programs and make employees at the program level feel incompetent.   Corporate departments immediately escalate issues to their senior leaders and will include everyone in emails to reprimand individuals (your role doesn't matter - Program Directors get the same treatment).  While issues need to be addressed, there literally is no wiggle room for even a first time error - they simply go straight up the chain.   You dread emails from corporate because it's usually about something you did wrong, even if you do 99% of tasks correctly 99% of the time.

There is very limited insight into the performance, vision or goals of the organization.  There is a once a year publication that is sent out via email, but not all staff have or can access email.

-Limited career opportunities: The company touts the internal career opportunities and it's particularly inspiring how the CEO literally worked his way from the bottom to the top.  However, opportunities really only exist if you are in a clinical or corporate career path.  If you are in a support role, you typically have to wait for someone to move out of a role (so be content remaining in your role until the person in the role you want at your program retires), find your way into a corporate role (if available), hope you have leadership at your program willing and able to support your development to help you be more flexible for opportunities or be great at smooth talking your way up the ladder.

Programs become possessive of staff (I've been told transfers can be blocked by a program) which leads to undermining other programs in an attempt to gain access to strong talent.

-Drama:  Backstabbing, undermining, and gossip are a significant issue at the program level.  Although relationships among employees is frowned upon, there's no lack of "icky" and sketchy interpersonal stuff going on between employees.  Sadly, some are even open about their intent on sleeping around with other employees and will specifically target new employees.  

Unfortunately there is also theft by employees at the program level – from large amounts of money to electronics (someone actually walked out of work with a large TV from a program!).  It makes it a challenge to trust your coworkers, which impacts the vibe of the program.

HR isn’t much help at the program level because they are simply hired as office assistants given basic HR duties.  Hiring, terminations and employee relations are all handled by Program Directors who are untrained on how to handle HR matters while keeping employment law in mind.  Those assistants with actual HR experience (some are certified professionals) are not empowered to utilize their skills and knowledge at the program level.

-Pay: This is an issue in the non-profit industry overall, however, JRI says they pay competitively, which isn’t the case in most instances.  My program has had many candidates turn down the opportunity because they make significantly more at other comparable agencies.  If you won’t accept the pay offered then you are automatically generalized as someone who doesn’t have a genuine passion for this type of work.  Pay increases are inconsistent – even if your commitment to work excellence is extremely obvious there is often push back by leaders outside of the program.

pros: Work environment is collaborative. Managers and Supervisors are encouraging, dedicated to the work, families and supporting a learning and professional growth environment. Insightful, in touch and talented to support their staff in the difficult work they do with the families that JRI serves. Always available to their staff. Value the work and creative to approach challenges.
cons: The PTO 2017 compensation is critical to employees. It is like going to the bank and depositing your money and when you with draw what you have put in, they only get half back. This doesn't work. It is basic math. Many people are discouraged to understand how JRI came up with a package that essential takes away the a hard earned work/life balance benefit".

review_title: Please reconsider the change in compensation
pros: I have worked for JRI for several years. Generally, it is an excellent organization. I appreciate the emphasis on training, supervision, commitment to social justice, and the goal that employees stay for their entire careers. I love my team and the support I get from the people I work with. I always feel encouraged to go out on a limb to try new things and grow as a clinician. Within my office, I feel fully supported. Benefits are really good compared to other agencies.
cons: Recently, the way community-based employees are being paid has changed, which makes me feel underappreciated by senior management. I am really concerned that I am going to get burnt out within a year or two if I am in this rat race of billing, and I have watched excellent clinicians leave due to the demands of productivity. While 32 billable hours was difficult before the change, I now must meet 20 hours (vs. 16 in the old system) before seeing money above a relatively low base pay. As others have mentioned, I am now stressed about taking one day off, let alone more than that, as it affects my whole week. We do not see any incentive in going to trainings anymore, since we aren't compensated over the base rate, and still must make productivity in that week. It was hard enough to take a self-care day before, and now it feels impossible. Enjoying the holidays that JRI observes is nearly impossible since we suffer financially (and end up having to work). Although presented as though we would make more money using this new pay rate, I can only imagine that we would make more money if we were billing 32-40 hours every single week (which really equates to working 60 hours).

pros: Our Division joined JRI through a merger just six months ago.  The process has been positive from top to bottom and our integration has been one marked by respect and open conversation.  JRI's reputation as a leader in social justice has already been confirmed a thousand times over.  JRI is culturally responsive, trauma-informed, and possesses all of the qualities of a leader.  This is no coincidence with people like Andy Pond and Jenn Miguel at the helm.  JRI is a great place to be and I'm proud to work here.
cons: Nothing to note in this section

review_title: Rewarding work and good opportunity for Growth in the field.
job_title: Case Manager in Jamaica Plain, MA
pros: Lots of opportunities for growth in the company. My supervisor was very supportive, encouraging and well educated in her  field. I learned so much from her. The clients were great to work with too. excellent training.
cons: The pay was  poor but benefits were okay and we had to use our car to drive the clients at work alot which cost a lot of money. There was some turn over mostly due to poor pay and alot of staff were on work visas for  a year and went back when it ended.

pros: Tuition reembursement and experience.
cons: Over worked and underpaid. Most workers are hourly but management treats them to be salary and refuse to pay them the overtime hours they work to finish paperwork, etc. There is not a set structure in management so everything falls through the cracks and nothing that is talked about for improvement gets implemented. Constantly get called to work on your days off and being "mandated" to stay on shift due to lack of employees being scheduled to come in.

review_title: Pretty good but room for imp[rovement
pros: Good benefits.  Little to no office politics.  Pleasant environment.  Good IT support.  Friendly co-workers.  Diverse staff.
cons: Managers are expected to do administrative tasks which can be demoralizing and time consuming.  My supervisor is kind and supportive but so busy that we can go for several days without interacting.  It seems as though everyone is expected to do the job of 2 or 3 people.

pros: Great work atmosphere. Incredible coworkers who are always willing to guide you. Amazing supervisors. Always feel supported. Good benefits. 401K and Pension plan. Free top of the line dental. Pretty good health insurance. A lot of ways to move up in this company, also a lot of ways to further your education.
cons: Very hard to learn the whole system. Billing, notes, and lesson plans are difficult to navigate when you are new. Need to master all three to become full time. Coworkers are always willing to help. JRI should focus more on this during our training instead of other random smaller trainings. One of the biggest things that stood out to me when I was in training was the way trainers would encourage self care. "What are you going to do today for self care?" Big question during trainings to make sure employees were taking care of themselves because of the emotionally stressful job we have. New compensation model is ridiculous. There were no side by side models handed out to staff to compare the old and the new. Instead, we were given confusing information and told we had to sign the new model immediately. We were told if we billed 40 hours a week for 46 weeks a year, we would make X amount of money. Billing that much for that long is NOT sustainable. We will burnout and quit and JRI will have to train new employees. If we are going to have our basepay hours upped, we deserve those hours to be PRORATED on weeks when there is a holiday, otherwise we have to work on holiday's in order to make enough money that week to pay our bills. New compensation model does not allow me to afford my life if I do not work on holidays, take PTO, or am sick. It is unfair to expect the same amount of billing and taking more money out of our paychecks because of things we deserve. Prorate our hours! I will no longer attend trainings because they are not financially sustainable. JRI prides itself on everything they changed with this new model. This is not what we signed up for as a whole. JRI was rated a top place to work... don't think this will happen in the future and I see a lot of people leaving the program. If I bill 40 hours a week, it really means I'm working 60 with traveling between clients and not being able to bill for speaking with certain collaterals as health insurance does not allow it. Change the model of people will quit. Listen to the employees or you will lose them. Show us side by side models. Don't make the program directors take the heat for changes you make. It is unfair.

review_title: JRI is an excellent company to work for that truly cares about their clients, and their staff
pros: The work is challenging but with lots of personal and professional growth. Training is the best. I am constantly stimulated by new knowledge even after many, many years in the field. Our Program Director is very supportive, understanding and fair. Expectations and standards of care are clear, as they should be. The work environment is pleasant, my colleagues are terrific. And there is lots of room for growth. I am part time by choice, but could easily be happy working full time. I am quite satisfied with my compensation. I do use my own car to see clients, but mileage is reimbursed. Also, additional expenses have been reimbursed  with no problem.
cons: Hours can be later in the day, as most children need to be seen after school. There is a lot of paperwork. However, in my years of experience, no more than other agencies. I was provided a laptop, which has been an enormous help. I do have to travel between offices, and do some additional travel. But again, mileage is reimbursed. I've gone to two major conferences in the past year, all paid by JRI. Communication between team members is sometimes inconsistent, but the team has been working on this. There is more hours/demand for work than what I expected. I started out with just 4 hours/week a year ago, and am easily up to 20 hours most weeks now. I have to work on balancing my chosen personal life goals with my work at JRI, as JRI could easily take over. Time management skills and discipline in meeting goals are a must.

review_title: Leader of social justice for their clients and their employees who serve them
pros:
A sense of pride knowing the great work and services that are being provided within every JRI program.  JRI has high standards in terms of service and physical plant.  While I don't have direct interaction with JRI clients, I know the accounting work that I do supports the program and that gives back a feeling of accomplishment.

Tremendous benefits, especially for a non-profit, including a fully-funded vested Pension Plan in addition to an employer-matching 401(k) plan.  There are no other non-profits in Mass offering such a Pension Plan at this time.  Also, very generous Paid Time Off packages, affordable health care, and more.  

JRI loves to promote from within.  There are many great managers and leaders, who are very smart and innovative.  JRI is growing rapidly and they look internally first for the best candidates.  The development and support I've received over the years has been amazing!  I also enjoy the professional and family-friendly work environment.
cons: A few growing pains.  JRI has almost doubled in size within the last 5-10 years.  With that JRI has lacked some of the systems at times to be efficient.  Additionally, there were times when we were short-staffed because of the rapid growth; however, the management was always supportive of hiring additional staff as-needed.  In regards to working in the Corporate Office, it can be very difficult to quickly train new staff because JRI is so diverse in the services offered that it takes quite some time to get the new staff up to speed.

pros: People, recognition of competence, wide contribution of all, mutual respect, happy & encouraging culture.  Everyone across the board actually walks the walk. Everyone is personable, competent, smart, and, most importantly, honest while at the same time knowing how to laugh and have fun. Work is not drudgery! Oh, and great CEO!
cons: Everyone is smart and dedicated. I have to be on my game all the time!  There really are no negatives -- even though the agency is huge, employees have many opportunities to meet each other, work together, and develop relationships.

pros: Management cares about their employees and there are many opportunities for professional growth.  The culture of JRI makes programs feel like they are a part of something greater.  Great benefits!
cons: The pay for direct care employees is too low.  Despite knowing that in this field of work, programs are losing good employees.

review_title: Know what you are in for before accepting that job offer
pros: Most of the JRI programs do a good job in helping some very needy people with very challenging mental and physical problems.
cons:
JRI is not a welcoming environment for all groups of people and that is even more true for minority group (of all kinds).  I noticed three main reasons for that:

1) The majority of the staff are either family or connected to each other somehow; you will always feel like an outsider looking in.  Again that is especially true if you are of any minority group.  

2) Some of the Programs management team are just plain racist ; they simply do not want to see anyone who does not look like them around (the Boston programs are an exception for the most part). At least not at any position other than low level ones.  This reason supports very well the first reason, they hire who they like and if they finally hire someone other than themselves, they fire you as soon as you show interest in getting promoted to a higher position or they make your life  so difficult and miserable you hand up quitting.  And since they groom from within the next generation of management the chances of getting a person of a minority group to become part of that inner management cycle is dead on arrival.

3) Lastly, they protect each other, so there is no place and no-one to report occurrences of mistreatment to.  It is a full cycle!!!! 

My purpose for writing this review is to give potential employees the other side of those glorious reviews (to be fair I am sure some of them are genuine!)

After reading this review if you still want to accept the job offer at least you can do so with your eyes open.

Good Luck!!!!

pros: I found JRI when I was a junior in College and of course can only speak to my experience which I have to say was nothing short of an incredible launching pad to my career. I had an amazing supervisor who took me under her wing and taught me everything I know today. I was molded into a great social worker, and JRI helped me pay for my tuition, and supported me obtaining a higher degree 100%. I was not just trained to be great for JRI; my experience has helped me grow personally and professionally in so many different ways. I worked along side some of the best of the best, and opportunities are always awaiting for those who are willing to put themselves out there and jump in to the work.
cons: I've seen many changes to the company over the years, including the community based division and I have always felt as though the communication about the changes have not always been well received by those doing the actual work. Working in the community, although incredibly rewarding, can have a lot of drawbacks. As a woman, I felt unable to continue my professional career with the company because I was not sure  how I would have  been able to balance a family with the work I was doing.

pros: Excellent benefits, quality employees, very supportive environment. Understands the need for work-life balance while also focusing on clients.
cons: Salary on the lower side but benefits are industry-leading. Some staff are subpar but that's to be expected everywhere. Difficult to always be on with tough clients.

review_title: Great company, well-run program, interesting and exciting work
pros: Helping under-served populations, diverse clientele, benefits package gives decent vacation time and health insurance with the chance to earn a pension, job stability, great co-workers, team setting.
cons: Low paying jobs, state controlled positions and contracts limit upward mobility, frequent turn-over of clients due to nature of the program, unable to work with clients until the completion of their treatment.

pros:
Fantastic kids
Learn about hard work and commitment
Learn about trauma informed teaching and therapy
Great co workers - team work
cons:
Very cliquey 
Starts with favoritism from the top of the program;  small
select group in administrative inner circle and if the top ends up not liking you for whatever reason- they'll find a way to fire you.
Example: miscommunication about ordering a cake
Many things get covered up and no responsibility is taken by Admin.  Example: assaults on staff

review_title: Great place to work, great place to grow
pros: If social justice is your passion--no matter where that leads you--you'll find a place at JRI that works for you. JRI is one of the few companies (nonprofit and otherwise) that still has an active, generous defined benefit pension plan.
cons: Money in human services is not always great--but through hard work and promotion you can make a career at JRI.

review_title: Commitment to social justice across programs
pros: Staff development and self care are incredibly important at JRI.  Compared to other places I've worked, JRI is by far the most advanced in this area.  I always feel like my voice is heard and my opinion matters.  There are always trainings going on and we have the opportunity to connect with some of the leaders in the field of psychological trauma.
cons: There is a wide geographic region covered which will hopefully equate to the development of new programs in the future.

pros: Great co-workers, supportive supervisors, great facilities, benefits
cons: understaffed (a lot of mandating and being asked to pick up extra shifts),

pros: The people at JRI genuinely care about the people they serve and that is evident at all levels at the Agency. The focus is on the well being of its people whether it is the clients or employees.
cons: This is not per say a 'Con' but an observation; this is a very large agency and learning about all the different programs take a lot of time and can be overwhelming.

pros: Good benefits, training's are paid by the company
cons: Company wants employees think this is a career but there is very little room for growth. High stress and can be put in very dangerous situations. Pay is awful $12.50 and hour- minimum wage is $11 for very high expectations.

pros: Amazing staff and management. Each program strives working toward the overall mission of social justice. This is a place to have a meaning career. The benefits , time off and pension are incredible as the CEO is an incredible leader.
cons: None- there really aren’t any. The social work field in itself can be challenging and emotionally draining. By the agency does everything to try to support and prioritize staff self care.

pros: JRI values and mission is true from top to bottom. JRI values employees as much as those we serve. Working hard on the behalf of all for equality and opportunities. They support employees to grow on their own professional path supporting new ideas and offering guidance to improve skills
cons: Pay is clearly not as high as the business world but very competitive for non profit sector

pros: Great team-oriented work environment. The girls, clinical staff, and residential staff at the Walden Street School are so dynamic and their enthusiasm is contageous. You will learn a LOT about trauma-informed approaches.
cons: The working environment is often stressful, hazardous, and exhausting. However, there is a strong support system of supervisors who provide excellent training.

review_title: Benefits are the best I've ever seen
pros: JRI takes good care of its employees -- with incredible health care, retirement (even a pension, almost unknown in this day and age), and professional development benefits.   Getting a holiday bonus is much-appreciated and makes you feel like your efforts are being noticed.
cons: Some would say that salaries are not competitive with similar companies, but honestly in many ways the benefits are more important to me and more than make up for the difference.

pros: Working at JRI has been an amazing experience.  The commitment to the mission is an integral part of the work - so every day we get to pursue social justice.  We get to help children and families move forward.  Plus, the benefits package, tuition reimbursement, and overall employee support make the job even better.
cons: The work can be challenging at times but the company's commitment to support and the benefits package show dedication to supporting staff through these challenges.

review_title: great parent company, some individual programs are deplorable
job_title: Choose Not to Answer in Boston, MA
pros: great benefits, generous time off, if you can get it.
cons: program managers do as they please, it hurts employees, there needs to be more oversight and not favoritism, management allows this to go on. employees are not allowed to talk to management about issues.

review_title: Clients and their families matter least
job_title: Clinical Team Member in Willimantic, CT
pros: Youre able to create your own "flexible" schedule, though your schedule becomes over whelming and unmanagable
cons:
The connecticut program of JRI works
to maximize its profit at any cost. Works for (not with) Department of Children and Families and together frequency make questionable treatment decisions against professional, ethical and personal values. When this issue was brought to the attention of program management, all employees were told during a team meeting that we need to put those ethical values aside or find employment elsewhere.

review_title: not happy about how things have turned out
pros:
incredibly good benefits
support for professional development, personal and staff-wide
employees feel appreciated and well-treated
cons:
salaries remain low
not being supported to transition to a new position within the agency despite 12 years of highly successful employment

pros: 1. Relaxing work environment. 2. Friendly colleagues. 3. The work was not very stressful, leaving the flexible time to study or entertainment. 4. Great benefits, great medical insurance plan, dental plan, etc.
cons:
1. Work is not very challenging. I needed to keep studying during my leisure time.
2. Not recommend for OPT holders, the E-verify may not work for the application of OPT extension.
3. The salary is not very competitive since it is a non-profit organization.

pros: JRI is a supportive company that offers a tremendous benefits package to employees.  JRI offers staff the training needed to best serve our clients using a trauma informed approach.  JRI offers career development and trainings and can offer an employee varied experiences across numerous types of program settings.
cons: Working in the human services field can be challenging in terms of balancing one's family and self-care needs but it can also be very rewarding.

pros: Amazing co-workers.  JRI hires great people.  Benefits package is excellent.
cons: Pay is very poor for community-based staff, with worse than average productivity expectations.  The pay package starting in 2017 will make it more difficult to earn a real paycheck.  PTO and training are available, but there are monetary consequences.
