review_title: Excellent place to advance for motivated, caring professionals
pros: Mission of social justice, applied to a broad range of issues. Trauma informed care for clients, supportive staff environment. Tuition reimbursement available. Promotion opportunities. Defined benefit pension plan. Good healthcare plan, including dental.
cons: Salaries, like much of human services, are lower than the private sector.

job_title: Residential Counselor Supervisor in Attleboro, MA
pros: The program in JRI that I worked for, Attleboro Center, is a short term residential, specializing in the stabilization and continuing treatment of adolescents and their families. The staff and management, including Clinical team, was outstanding at their jobs and far exceeded my expectations as an employee and counselor. Communication was always open and it was a pleasure to be a part of the team.
cons: -All training weren't on site

review_title: The place for leaders in social justice
pros: The mission is social justice, the way we  pursue the work is in a hundred different ways, all linked by their passion for the communities we serve. Benefits are the best in the field.
cons: Starting pay for direct care staff is low, advocacy with the state(s) is needed to improve rates.  Some of jobs are high-demand and require active self-care to build resilience.

pros: JRI is about doing the right thing - for the people they support, the agencies they work with and their employees.  It starts at the top and goes all the way through.  The people here work hard and care about the people served, what they do, and each other.  I love my job - been here 20+ yrs.
cons: The downside is that there is always more to do,.

pros: Being valued, flexibility, growth opportunities, excellent benefits. I love working in an atmosphere that supports diversity and respect with dignity. It is a great feeling to know I can make a difference in someone's life, and JRI's support has made a difference in mine.
cons: It would be great to have better financial aid or loan forgiveness options when working in the not for profit arena and social justice communities.

pros: JRI has been flexible when my personal circumstances have warranted it.  It is a dynamic, growing organization committed to social justice.  The benefits are significantly better than any other non-profit I've ever worked at.
cons: As the agency grows there are some expected growing pains that are being worked out.

pros: Nothing at all don’t do it
cons: No meal breaks, struggle to get switched out for a bathroom break, getting mandated constantly due to understaffing. Higher ups are very shady and condescending towards res counselors. We get treated like the bottom of the barrel. Unsafe work environment, the kids throw temper tantrums when needs are not met and res counselors deal with it and are put in unsafe circumstances. The kids are spoiled and get gifts even after verbally or physically assaulting staff

job_title: Assistant Program Director in Tewksbury, MA
pros: exceptional agency.  I have worked for JRI for 27 years and have seen it grow into an incredible agency without losing it's "human touch" for the staff and clients we serve.  The benefits are exceptional and the programs all have exceptionally high standards in terms of providing nurturing, supportive environments for the clients and staff.
cons: I can't think of any "cons"

pros:
Dedication to excellence on every level; service delivery, staff development and training. strategic planning.
Constant assessment of  strengths but more importantly areas of need and developing solutions. This occurs in terms of service gaps as well as central service supports
Consistently on cutting edge in terms of treatment modalities, service design and systems.
Excellent benefits
cons: Challenges for an agency this large consistently involve communication; how, who, when, what

review_title: Funny how only management gives 4-5* on glassdoor, someone hired an outside firm to boost ratings
pros:
Very good benefits and depending on placement good coworkers.  But the only problem is that the only people that are able to stick around to get the full benefit of all those benefits are the upper management and clinicians or anyone that doesn't deal with the clients as much. 

Direct managers that worked the floor know the stress and try to help.
cons:
You'll quickly find out that the memos saying "Direct staff are the backbone to the company" are just words with nothing behind them.  Because in reality you're just a number that is replaced by anyone that can fill out an application.  

If you are direct staff be prepared to be mentally and physically abused and be burnt out after a year.  

Because of the burnt out and low pay there is very high turnover.  So we lose alot of good employees that just can't take it anymore or find better paying jobs.  What is left are lower quality staff and constant stream of new employees.  Which means all the work and responsibility falls on the few great veterans.  

And since you'll always be understaffed be prepared to be constantly forced because you are a responsible and come to work.  But sadly the change to PTO just made it easier for those staff that are always late or calling out to do whatever with little problems.

Since staffing is so tight and high ratios and turnover is so high.  The worst staff get to stick around a very long time because you need the numbers to fill shifts.

pros: I have worked at other human service agencies and am always amazed at the quality of care and treatment provided by JRI.  There is a huge commitment to staff development and retention...I have been allowed to grow and develop and have been recognized for my performance...JRI  offers benefits that cannot not be matched by most other agencies...
cons: The human service profession is stressful by nature...

pros:
Good Supervision
Talented co workers 
Flexible Schedule
cons:
New compensation model does not promote self-care, but promotes burn out.
Unofficial expectation to work 50 plus hours a week
Productivity requirement of 20 hours a week
Cliquey work environment 
Trainings , holidays and sick time don't count towards productivity requirement

pros: The satisfaction of being able to see how the participants grow through a therapeutic mentorship, can not be described with words. Although, that is the best thing of any public service job.
cons: The distance of traveling and the ware-down of the car. And having to tell my story over and over, can be very difficult.

review_title: Ok for first human service position
pros: Good trainings, great staff- good place to build clinical skills and learn
cons: Unrealistic expectations of employees; things are always changing and the top people do not support management to then allow for timely changes by employees

pros: It is obvious that JRI values advancing social justice issues. The focus and attention to diversity and individuality is evident. The training and support staff receive to care for children and families is far beyond anything I've ever experienced.
cons: There are no Cons in this area but this app is requiring me to enter at least 20 words in this section.

pros: This is a very good place to work the people are friendly and you  can always get the help you need from anyone whether it be work family issues or struggling with a family you are working with.  Its family oriented
cons: I used to live in Boston I now currently lived in Rhode Island.  I'm working at JRI in JP and I truly love it here and the commute is terrible but at the end of the day it is worth it to work with the families in need.   But  I have been working here for the past 8 months and I recently found out that we are making  $10.40 cents cause I never check my paystub until recently.   This a growing company and the amount of work and paperwork that we all do we deserve better.   There are some day that I cant even afford to by food at my home after I get paid.   For the first time in my life I'm  happy that I was homeless years ago because I have my section 8 voucher if it wasn't for that I would have been homeless again over the past 8 months.  I'm surviving by the skin of my teeth and I have a car note and other bills to pay and putting 60dollars on in my car every two weeks

review_title: Rewarding but tough place to work
pros: Working with kids, great school environment, great clinical leadership, good company compared with other residential facilities
cons: Pay not great, administrators particularly in residential department are in a disconnect with the supervisors and floor staff who often get the short end of the stick and no voice in day to day operations so there is high turnover

pros: Leadership in a company starts at the top and cascades down. It's obvious that JRI cares about about their employees.
cons: I'm hard pressed to think of any cons. What makes a company successful is it's employees. Make them feel more involved.

job_title: Case Manager in Fall River, MA

cons: Negative work environment. Unsupported supervisors. Extremely high turnover. Job specific training is poor

job_title: Corporate Role in Fall River, MA
pros: Great benefits!  Sr. Mgt really cares about each employees career development.  Employees are very intelligent and strive to provide the best possible care to clients.
cons: I can't think of anything except that the agency is very spread out throughout three states and can be difficult to meet with each program if you're in a corporate role.

review_title: It's not a job, it's a meaningful career
pros: Amazing place to not only work, but have a career. Excellent benefits, leaders in the field first class co workers

review_title: JRI assists employees with their professional growth and provides never ending learning opportunities through training!

cons: Great agency to work for that is continuing to expand!

pros: JRI has invested in my career and provided me with many opportunities to grow. They have a great benefit package! Their commitment to Social Justice is evidenced by their commitment to their clients and training of their staff.

pros: Working at JRI you will surround yourself with high quality, generally very caring individuals. If there is a need, there is always support to meet it. There are many people served and served well in this agency.
